The number of spikes observed in the BZ reaction depends on various factors, including the concentrations of the reactants and the catalyst, as well as the reactor volume and temperature.

To determine the maximum number of spikes observed in the BZ reaction, we can use the Oregonator model, which is a simplified mathematical model that describes the behavior of the BZ reaction. The Oregonator model is represented by a set of nonlinear ordinary differential equations, which can be solved numerically to obtain the time evolution of the concentrations of the different species involved in the reaction.

However, solving the Oregonator model requires advanced mathematical techniques and specialized software, which are beyond the scope of this platform. Moreover, the number of spikes observed in the BZ reaction is not solely determined by the concentrations of the reactants and the catalyst, but also depends on other factors such as the geometry of the reactor and the presence of impurities.
